children.subject: Would it make sense to shift one tech from each towards Spring 2022, and fill them in with arbitrary upper divs?
Spring 2021 and Fall 2021 look like a lot of work. I would take at least a technical out on each semester there

Imo Data100 (CS C100) should be taken before 189 - I recommend swapping one of your sp21 courses with it. Its a gentler introduction to common topics such as linear regression, logistics regression, classification, and cross validation. That way when encountering the topics in 189 you can focus less on the bare bones of the topic and more on the nuances. 

Caveat: I took Shewchuck's version of 189 in spring 2018, which felt like a really natural extension of Data100 (I took them one semester after another), but I think the fall version of CS189 with fall profs might be slightly different, so the topics may not correspond as much.

Schedule-wise, people typically recommend taking 127 before 189 to really get the most out of 189/be solidly prepared for it mathematically. You may also consider taking one or two relevant Stats/Math courses if you plan to do a 5th year masters in ML/AI, since you will need a solid math background for that and probably some of your undergraduate courses too, like 189/192/127, etc. 

But also make sure you have really strong reasons both for doing the masters and for rushing through undergrad. If you have absolutely 0 interest in anything but EECS/AI/ML at this school, that's okay, but keep in mind you may need to build connections with professors, try research or tutoring, etc. before grad school, and this also puts a load on your schedule. You also decrease the amount of summers you get to try an internship by rushing, and this means you don't get as many chances sampling companies/figuring out your ideal career! And don't underestimate the possibility of changing your mind throughout this process, being open and flexible is a good thing. My first year, I wanted to graduate early as well, and took summer courses for this reason, but recently I found an interesting application of my CS degree in another academic field and I plan to double major, take 9 semesters, have time for research and getting to know people here, etc. My story/advice is not that important, but keep in mind you are studying CS and that means you can probably afford to enjoy school a little longer if you want to (: Lastly, consider the idea of doing your masters outside of Berkeley--it may not be likely, considering Berkeley is a top CS school, but you may find yourself wanting a change of scenery at some point.

history.content:
If you want ML, you need to know at least some multivariable calculus. Honestly, if you understand the stuff in 16ab and single variable calc and the idea of functions that take in multiple values and output multiple values (aka numerical vectors), you can learn it pretty quickly (key things to know: partial derivatives, chain rule for partial derivatives, d(d(f)/dx)/dy = d(d(f)/dy)/dx in most cases, gradient vector and directional derivatives, and jacobian). 

EECS 126 is the only core ML course your missing (Cores == 188 (For RL), 189, 126, and 127). 

I'm not sure how applicable 100 is after 189. Having "data science" officially on your resume helps, but I took it after 189 pseudo online over the summer and knew everything except Pandas/Seaborn.

Part of this depends on what you are looking to do here. In most cases, you do wanna take CS 189 that semester you have because you could put it on resume or CV for jobs or grad school.

I honestly don't recommend trying to graduate early unless money is an issue. You can gain so much more background that will help you whether you go industry or grad school, and you can find classes you might find more enjoyable. Going for grad school especially, you just weaken your application by graduating early (less time for classes and research). Also be wary of taking more than 3 techs a semester, but you know yourself better than I do.

Idk how much it matters for 5th years masters, but it helps for grad school in general to have taken a grad class, so maybe add one it (but needs to be on application when you apply, so if you apply out of college, needs to at least be taken that fall).

In general, it helps to cover the core stuff you wanna do as soon as possible (eg 189) before the more specialized stuff (eg info 159). 189 can help you get stuff in ML in general, but 159 only helps with NLP, so you get more options that way. Like for me I did that with the AI courses and that let me get research opportunities to help for grad school, while someone else prob took 162 and such early and got some great internships early on (not that you cant get both). You could also move stuff like 186 and 154 to your final semester to help with your goal. This would also let you take 126 and 127 before 189, where it will help you much more

All the courses you picked (that are CS at least)  are definitely applicable to exactly what you seem to wanna do. If you find yourself liking any particular areas within AI/ML/DS, feel free to dive in there while still in undergrad. The classes might not be exactly covering the AI/ML aspect (that tends to be saved for grad school), but they can give you backings for it and help you truly understand if you wanna go grad in that area

E.g.

-Computer vision: 184 graphics, EE 120 (signals & systems), EE 123 (digital system processing)

-NLP: ling 100 (major intro) teaches you a lot of basics

-Robotics: EECS 106a (intro to robotics), EE 120, EE C128 (control systems)

Hi all, I'm a first-year L&S intended-CS major who is considering attempting to graduate in 3 years. I'm planning to take my R1B online at a CC this coming summer; I've already passed out of Math 1A/1B, and have 40 transfer units from HS. Out of all CS areas of interest, AI/ML are what I'm most interested in. Any feedback on my current plan, and/or what additional courses I should finish up Spring 2022 with (since they won't be required to graduate), is highly appreciated! I'm also interested in potentially combining this with the "5th" year BA/MS program.

* going towards L&S 6-unit non-major upper div requirement
